dt: used in addressing or referring to reigning sovereigns and their consorts
{bc}greatness or splendor of quality or character

et: Middle English {it}maieste{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}majesté{/it}, from Latin {it}majestat-, majestas{/it}; akin to Latin {it}major{/it} greater
shortdef: —used in addressing or referring to reigning sovereigns and their consorts

dt: {bc}a crime (such as treason) committed against a sovereign power
{bc}an offense violating the dignity of a ruler as the representative of a sovereign power
{bc}a detraction from or affront to dignity or importance

et: Middle French {it}lese majesté{/it}, from Latin {it}laesa majestas{/it}, literally, injured majesty
shortdef: a crime (such as treason) committed against a sovereign power
an offense violating the dignity of a ruler as the representative of a sovereign power
a detraction from or affront to dignity or importance
